p: Recently, there has been a great interest regarding the role of dietary antioxidants in neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimerâ€™s disease (AD) [ 12]. Although pomegranate is rich in antioxidant polyphenols and oxidative stress may play a key role in neurodegenerative disease, few in vivo and in vitro studies analyzed its activity as a potential inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase (AChE) [ 12, 13, 14]. In AD transgenic mice, a dietary supplementation with 4% of pomegranate attenuated the oxidative damage and reduced the activity of AChE, restoring its normal levels [ 12]. Furthermore, an ethanol extract of pomegranate leaves or peels showed good AChE inhibition activities [ 13, 14].
